keyTakeAways: Christopher Moynihan, a former Capitol rioter pardoned by President Donald Trump in 2021, was arrested in October 2025 for allegedly threatening to kill House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries.
Moynihan allegedly sent texts in which he threatened to kill Jeffries, stating 'I will kill him for the future' and 'Even if I am hated he must be eliminated.'
The arrest comes amid a significant increase in threat assessments to lawmakers, with Capitol Police reporting around 14,000 such cases by the end of 2025.
Moynihan was originally sentenced in 2023 to 21 months in prison and 36 months of supervised release, but received a full pardon along with over 1,500 others involved in the Jan. 6 Capitol riot.
This incident highlights growing concerns that blanket pardons of Capitol rioters may allow violent individuals to re-enter society with no accountability.
House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries has criticized the pardons, noting that many pardoned individuals have committed new crimes, placing law enforcement at increased risk.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A man who participated in the January 6, 2021 Capitol riot, Christopher Moynihan, was arrested in October 2025 for allegedly threatening to kill U.S. House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries. Moynihan, who was originally sentenced to 21 months in prison and 36 months of supervised release in 2023, received a full pardon by President Donald Trump in 2021 as part of a blanket pardon of over 1,500 Capitol riot defendants. Court documents reveal that Moynihan allegedly sent threatening texts in which he stated, 'I will kill him for the future,' and 'Even if I am hated he must be eliminated.' The arrest was prompted by intelligence from the FBI and carried out by the New York State Police. This incident has reignited concerns about the safety of lawmakers, as Capitol Police report a sharp rise in threat assessments—projecting 14,000 cases by year-end. The case has drawn criticism from Jeffries, who argues that pardoned individuals should not be allowed to re-enter society without accountability, raising broader questions about the impact of blanket pardons on public safety and democratic institutions.
title: Pardoned Capitol rioter arrested for allegedly threatening to kill Hakeem Jeffries
